monogr.title: A touch-stone for a Christian : Wherein is shewed, how a man may know, whether he be the Temple of the Holy Ghost, hath a sauing faith, be the childe of God, hath truly repented, and (in one word) be a Christian in deed, or in name onely. By Thomas Broade
monogr.author: Broad, Thomas

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
FOrasmuch as all men almost perswade themselues, that they are led by the Spirit of God, and are indeed Christs faithfull Disciples: howsoeuer the Spirit hath spoken euidently; 1. Tim. •…
that in the latter times iniquitie shall abound; and Christ himselfe complaining of these daies, hath said, Luk. 18. When the Sonne of man commeth, shall he finde faith on the earth? I haue therfore thought it labour not ill bestowed, if I could teach thee (gentle Reader) how thou mightest know, and not be deceiued,
whether thou art indeede such a one, as most men vainly imagine themselues to be. If thou art a strong Christian, I need not teach it thee, as one that knoweth it already. But I haue written for the weake Christians sake, that he might receiue comfort, and be strengthned heereby: as also that the carelesse Christian awaking out of his sleepe of securitie, Ephes. 5. and standing vp from the dead, Christ might giue vnto him the light of his holy Spirit.

Now, whereas this my discourse is not fraught with out landish words, and filed phrases, such as are in great request amongst many: if by my plainnesse I shall bee offensiue vnto any, my Apologie for my selfe is briefly thus. Act. 18. Apollos was an eloquent man, as Saint Luke testifieth of him: and I see very many in all places, which in this point hold of Apollos. 1. Cor. 2. Paul shewed no such eloquence, as he himselfe saith of himselfe:
and it were not (I thinke) amisse, that some in some places should hold of Paul also. And then, if Paul doth first plant, and Apollos afterward with his sweet showres of eloquence doth water; there is great cause to hope, that God will giue greater increase, than hitherto hee hath done in many places. For indeed, there are too few in these daies which hold of Paul. Either we cannot plant, nor teach the plaine truth plainly: or if we can, straight we goe to watering, and striue to shew our eloquence. But God of his mercie send vs some such as Paul into his vineyard, which may plant, and labour more than they all: for vnlesse planting goe before watering, this kind of watering shall doe little good; 1. Cor. 1. especially seeing not many wise men after the flesh, but God hath chosen the foolish things of the world to confound the wise.

Surely, when I first left the Ʋniuersitie,
before I might publikely so doe, I beganne to instruct some priuately: and it is altogether incredible, how hardly they receiued euen milke, giuen also in the most easie and familiar manner that I could deuise. Since this time I haue bidden eloquence farewell: and mine only endeuour, and earnest praier, hath beene; that I might truly say with the Apostle,
• . Cor. 11. Though I bee rude in speaking, yet am I not so in knowledge. I hold of S. Paul▪ I would be exceeding plaine: for indeed, I seeke not to please thee with newfangled words and curious phrases, whereby I should become a Barbarian vnto some;
• . Cor. 14. but to haue thee please God with thy good works and plaine dealing, that so thou maist be accounted a good Christian of all. Bring not then any such mind to the reading of this Treatise: but seeing it teacheth a matter of greatest moment in these our carelesse daies,
reade it with good deliberation, ad in any wise beware of flattering thy selfe. Truly, if thou wouldest make a good vse heereof, I nothing doubt, but ere it were long, thou shouldest learne one good lesson, which many great Doctours shall neuer bee able to learne; namely, that thou thy selfe shalt be saued. Happie is hee that hath learned this lesson perfectly, and by heart: it will not a little reioice that mans heart euer after. This happinesse (gentle Reader) God of his mercie will grant vnto thee, vnlesse thou art mercilesse towards thy selfe, and louest thine owne miserie. Account it as a sure token of Gods goodwill, whensoeuer he bringeth a good booke vnto thine hands: and if thou wouldest not haue this token of his good will become a meanes of his greater displeasure, reade attentiuely, meditate diligently,
pray continually. Reade, meditate, pray, and God shall giue a blessing.
